I actually implemented HyperNeat in Java about a year ago. (I had some trou=
ble understanding what to do with ANJI and JNEAT too.)

It was designed to =
be able to modify the number of hidden layers. It was my first Java project=
 and it was unnecessarily complicated. However, a large chunk of the code w=
as ported from the original C++ HyperNeat. I'm sure it's reusable with a bi=
t tuning (e.g. not mutating number of layers and their connection patterns.=
)

If you want it, I will email you the code.
